Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Successive Disasters, Resilience, and Household Asset Management

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: While the COVID-19 pandemic has brought a range of regulations that exacerbated existing housing tensions or created new ones, households already living in conditions of socio-economic hardship or burdened by recovery from previous disasters have been particularly affected. This doctoral dissertation focuses on post-disaster asset allocation, specifically on housing and titles, to understand not only how humans respond to disasters and subsequent initiatives, but also how they create mechanisms for future resilience. It seeks to analyze whether demographic differences in homeownership influence outcomes in socio-economic capacity, social relations, decision-making, and personal autonomy after a disaster. The COVID-19 dimension offers a rare opportunity to analyze the factors associated with capacities to withstand different shocks. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student, this project will also engage a wider audience by broadly disseminating its findings to organizations and policymakers invested in disaster relief.<br/><br/>This ethnographic project centers on three neighborhoods devastated by successive disasters (a natural disaster, followed by COVID-19), and received differential post-disaster support. Post-disaster housing is explored as a site for analyzing the intersections between macro-level processes (disasters and subsequent initiatives) and their micro-level effects (intra-household dynamics). The researcher will collect data through participant observation, a survey and semi-structured interviews, to analyze a) how has the well-being of households been influenced by their degree of participation in post-earthquake initiatives; b) how does the response to COVID-19 and associated regulations affect intra-household dynamics; and c) how does successive disaster experience affect varied individual capacities and responses to the pandemic. The project offers the opportunity to gain comparative insights into how social relations are reconfigured within households and communities amidst successive disasters. The collected data will contribute to the anthropology of disasters, households, and assets. Focusing on social relations at the intersection of housing and disasters, close attention to COVID-19 will enhance the anthropological understanding of the social impact of epidemics.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant funded a 12-month study in a coastal Ecuadorian fishing village to examine the issues of displacement, reconstruction, and asset allocation amid disasters, including a 2016 earthquake and the COVID-19 pandemic. The co-PI employed participant observation, semi-structured interviews, and a household survey to analyze how cascading disasters with cumulative effects and subsequent recovery initiatives have impacted lives and relationships among residents, focusing specifically on gender relations. To consider the social changes and the factors that contribute to vulnerability and build resilience across generations, time, and place, this study investigated different modes of housing allocation, post-disaster governmental and nongovernmental intervention, and a range of socio-economic, political, and environmental shifts that have occurred in the last decade. These shifts include the decline of fishing, lack of remunerated work opportunities, and climate-change-induced disasters that have reshaped relationships and roles at the household and community level.

Collected data suggest that although post-earthquake initiatives offered new opportunities for some residents, the centralized and uneven reconstruction often failed to challenge, and even deepened, social inequities. Some organizations used the 2016 earthquake as an opportunity to implement initiatives intended to improve local people’s lives. These processes have led to several shifts. First, post-earthquake reconstruction processes reproduced some of the same cultural and gendered expectations they sought to challenge. Second, including women in post-earthquake interventions might have had a salutary effect on household and community relations, yet systemic challenges remained. Finally, some community-based interventions, have improved the professional and educational resilience and empowerment of women.

Specifically, the data demonstrates how cascading disasters with cumulative effects impact gender dynamics among rural men and women who live in socio-economically precarious conditions. Data suggests that women’s participation in disaster risk reduction and post-disaster resilience-building initiatives builds their and their household members’ resilience and improves their capacities to face future risks. These initiatives also improve their abilities to make life choices they had been denied (e.g., pursuing a job or education). Finally, instead of focusing only on suffering, the co-PI shifted the focus from disaster's immediate consequences to the processes of transformation in everyday spheres of activity, and long-term efforts of building equitable futures in the context of increased environmental and economic risk and disasters.

This work contributes to the studies of disasters, gender, and development. First, this study examines disasters of different scales over ten years, differing from most studies that have tended to focus on one major disaster. The study contributes to the scarce but growing literature that examines the cascading disasters with cumulative effects in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. Data provide crucial insights into how experiencing disasters, whether they are consecutive, overlapping, or cascading, shapes people’s capacities to face future ones. At present, this study is one of the few that examines the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic ethnographically; the co-PI suggests that the pandemic shifted people’s understanding of the impacts of previous disasters, as well as social and care relations that accompanied the reconstruction process.

Second, this study demonstrates the meaningful role that housing plays in disaster recovery. Housing is a meeting point for a wide range of values, scales of action, and relationships. To explore the intersections between disasters and subsequent development initiatives, as well as intra-household and micro-community dynamics, this study demonstrates that asset provision (or lack thereof) and other initiatives promoting equity impacted opportunities for women in the earthquake’s aftermath. My work contends that attention to gender when studying cascading disasters has been crucial in order to shed light on the different ways in which men and women negotiate recovery processes, outside support, professional and personal aspirations, abusive relationships, and other social, economic, and environmental changes. This study also demonstrates that gender-based housing recovery initiatives do not necessarily spark the expected long-term change. Acquiring a home does not inherently change relationships, particularly in a context where women are rarely homeowners and often depend on their partner’s income. As such, targeting women as agents of change often fails to challenge the status quo.  

Finally, this study draws on development studies and feminist economics, but assumes an expanded methodological framework. While much research on asset-based research draws on close-ended surveys, this study provides a comparative analysis of day-to-day intra-household and community relations, perceptions, and discourses that often make it more difficult to draw definitive conclusions. Analyzing these dynamics ethnographically is crucial for an anthropological understanding of the relationship between gender-focused post-disaster initiatives, gender relations within households, communities, and newly implemented initiatives. This study suggests that socio-cultural notions are often reproduced during reconstruction processes, particularly when local people emphasize self-sufficiency and traditional gender roles. However, employing concepts such as vulnerability and resilience, and basing findings on local women and men’s self-reported narratives collected in the field, can help us assess change, whether positive, negative, or a combination of the two.
